courses.title: TLC Retreat Camp DEI (Middle School): Belonging, Fairness & Teamwork
courses.description:
A youth-centered, sports-forward DEI experience designed for middle school campers. Campers explore identity (intersectionality), race & stereotypes, LGBTQIA+ belonging, and mental health through athlete stories, guided reflection, and team-based discussion.

This course is built for facilitated delivery during TLC Retreat Camp and includes a built-in anonymous question box workflow, discussion prompts, and a commitments wrap-up.
keyTakeaways: People are more than one thing—identities overlap.
Belonging is built through respect, curiosity, and fairness.
Allyship means supporting others, even when you don’t fully understand.
Asking for help and supporting friends are strengths.

modules.title: Welcome & Agreements
modules.description: Set the tone, create psychological safety, and introduce the anonymous question box.

lessons.title: Welcome: Strong Teams Build Belonging
lessons.description: Warm welcome and why these conversations matter for teammates.

body.title: Welcome
body.notes:
Facilitator script:
• At TLC, we build strong teams on and off the court.
• Everyone deserves respect and belonging.
• Today is about learning, curiosity, and teamwork—not being perfect.

content.text: At Tennis & Life Camps, we believe strong teams care for one another.
Today we’ll talk about identity, fairness, mental health, and how to be good teammates off the court.

lessons.title: Community Agreements
lessons.description: Group norms to help everyone feel safe participating.

body.prompt: Tap each agreement to show you understand it. You can always pass if you’re not ready to share.

items.label: Everyone gets a chance to share
You may pass at any time

lessons.title: Anonymous Question Box
lessons.description: Let campers submit questions anonymously to reduce pressure and increase honesty.

body.title: Ask a Question (Anonymous)
body.helperText:
Some questions are hard to ask out loud. That’s okay.
Write your question here—no names needed.
Adults will read selected questions respectfully and answer what they can.

category.label: Topic (optional)
options: Identity
Fairness & Race
LGBTQIA+ & Belonging
Mental Health
Something else

body.confirmationText: Thanks for your question. Curiosity helps us learn.

modules.title: Session 1: Identity & Intersectionality
modules.description: Whole-group video viewing, guided discussion, and reflection.

lessons.title: What is Intersectionality? (Watch Together)
lessons.description: Simple explanation that people have multiple identities at the same time.

body.notes:
Facilitator note: Play this to the whole group. Remind campers they can pass during discussion.
After video, ask: What stood out? What surprised you? How could this help us be better teammates?

lessons.title: Guided Discussion: People Are More Than One Thing
lessons.description: Whole-group discussion prompts in youth-friendly language.

body.title: Let’s Talk
prompts: What stood out to you from the video?
What are some different parts that make up who you are? (You can be general—no pressure.)
How might different parts of someone’s identity affect how they’re treated?
How could understanding this help us be better teammates?

lessons.title: Reflection (Write or Draw)
lessons.description: Choice-based reflection for different comfort levels.

body.title: Quick Reflection
body.prompt: Pick one: write 2–3 sentences OR draw a quick picture that shows something you learned.

options.label: Draw (or describe what you would draw)

modules.title: Session 2: Race, Stereotypes & Fairness
modules.description: Athlete stories + discussion focused on belonging and respect.

lessons.title: Video: Athlete Stories on Race & Stereotypes
lessons.description: Choose 1–2 short clips. (Placeholder links can be swapped.)

body.notes:
If you use two clips, keep total under ~7 minutes.
Goal: broaden representation (include at least one perspective beyond Black/White experiences).

lessons.title: Discussion: Belonging & Stereotypes
lessons.description: Prompts that emphasize similarities, respect, and team culture.

body.title: Let’s Talk
prompts: What challenges did the athlete(s) describe?
What felt similar across different stories?
How can stereotypes affect friendships or teams?
What makes someone feel welcome and respected in a group?
facilitatorTips: Keep it concrete (school, sports, team situations).
Avoid asking campers to share personal identity details.
If someone says something hurtful, redirect to impact and belonging.

modules.title: Session 2 Add-On: LGBTQIA+ & Belonging
modules.description: Staff-modeled inclusion segment focusing on respect and allyship.

body.notes:
Focus on respect and belonging; avoid jargon.
Remind campers: you don’t have to label yourself to be respectful.

lessons.title: Discussion: Respect & Allyship
lessons.description: Youth-friendly prompts that keep the focus on values.

body.title: Let’s Talk
prompts: What does it feel like to be accepted?
How can teammates show respect even if they don’t fully understand someone?
What does allyship look like at camp or school?
facilitatorTips: Keep the discussion values-based (respect, safety, belonging).
Do not ask campers to disclose identities.

modules.title: Session 3: Mental Health & Support
modules.description: Athlete stories + practical ways to support yourself and friends.

lessons.title: Video: Mental Health in Sports
lessons.description: Short athlete clips (Naomi Osaka / Kevin Love).

body.notes: Consider pausing once to ask: “What surprised you?” Keep it supportive and hopeful.

lessons.title: Discussion: Support & Strength
lessons.description: Prompts focused on help-seeking and being a good friend.

body.title: Let’s Talk
prompts: Why might someone feel nervous talking about mental health?
What are small ways to support a friend who is struggling?
Who are trusted adults you could talk to if you need help?
facilitatorTips: Avoid diagnosing or details about self-harm.
If a camper shares a safety concern, follow camp policy and notify leadership.

modules.title: Wrap-Up: Commitments
modules.description: Campers select actions they’ll take beyond camp.

lessons.title: Choose Your Commitments
lessons.description: Pick one commitment per topic + choose two to bring home.

body.title: Taking This Beyond Camp
body.helperText: Choose actions that help you be a better teammate, friend, and community member.

topics.title: Intersectionality
options: Explore the unique stories and backgrounds of people in your community to understand diverse experiences.
Speak up if you hear unfair words or see someone treated differently based on who they are.
Cheer for and encourage friends from different backgrounds in their activities and ideas.
Share what you learn about how different parts of identity can affect people’s lives.

topics.title: Race & Stereotypes
options: Learn about customs and stories of people from different races and backgrounds.
Speak out if you hear someone saying unfair things about people of different races.
Be a good friend and ally by celebrating and supporting friends from diverse backgrounds.
Teach yourself and others why stereotypes can be harmful.

topics.title: LGBTQIA+ & Belonging
options: Use respectful language and include others on teams and in friend groups.
If you hear someone being bullied or disrespected, speak up or get help from an adult.
Practice allyship: support others even when you don’t fully understand their identity.
Help create a team culture where everyone feels safe being themselves.

topics.title: Mental Health
options: Take breaks, sleep well, move your body, and eat foods that help your mind feel good.
Talk to a trusted adult if you or a friend needs help dealing with tough feelings.
Be a supportive friend by listening and checking in if someone seems down or stressed.
Learn a calming strategy (breathing, walk, music) and use it when you feel overwhelmed.

focusTwo.label: Pick TWO commitments you will focus on after camp

actionPlan.label: How will you do your two commitments? (1–3 sentences)

endDate.label: When will you complete your commitments?

lessons.title: Answering Anonymous Questions (Optional)
lessons.description: Staff can address selected questions respectfully at wrap-up.

body.title: Anonymous Questions
body.notes:
Facilitator steps:
• Pick 3–5 questions that are age-appropriate and values-based.
• Paraphrase if needed.
• Reinforce: respect, belonging, and asking adults for help.

content.text: Thank you for your curiosity and honesty.
We’ll answer a few anonymous questions in a respectful way.
You never have to share personal details to be part of a respectful team.
